awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Observing the Cosmic Evolution of Neutral Hydrogen
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, and neutral hydrogen atoms are thus an important constituent of interstellar gas in galaxies ? but also one of the most challenging to study. The faintness of neutral hydrogen emission means that it can only be detected beyond the nearby universe via long observations with large telescopes. A new telescope with improved sensitivity, the MeerKAT array, will examine how galaxies' neutral gas reservoirs have evolved over two thirds of the universe's history (i.e., the last nine billion years of cosmic time). It will determine how galaxies' neutral atomic hydrogen content relates to the properties of their stars, their environments, and their cosmic epochs. This will be compared with theoretical predictions in order to understand how gas flows into and out of galaxies and forms new stars while inside galaxies. The research will support the training of graduate and undergraduate students at the four universities; graduate students will gain additional experience in computation and statistics, research mentorship, education in STEM disciplines, and outreach to a variety of audiences.

This survey will probe neutral hydrogen (HI) in emission to an unprecedentedly high redshift of z = 1.45. The combination of individual and stacked HI detections ?  complemented by theoretical modelling, multiwavelength observations, and a rich z = 0 reference dataset ? will probe the evolution of (i) the baryonic Tully-Fisher relation, (ii) the HI mass function, and (iii) the dependence of galaxies' HI content on stellar and dark matter properties. OH megamasers detected as strong line emitters in the MeerKAT data will be used to place constraints on the cosmic history of gas-rich galaxy mergers. Both the HI survey data and the instructional modules used to provide student training will be publicly released as part of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project leveraged the deepest radio-wave interferometric data-cubes mapping neutral (atomic) hydrogen over the last nine billion years  of cosmic time. By so doing, we were able to examine how galaxies' neutral gas reservoirs evolved  over two thirds of the universe's history. The radio-wave data is from LADUMA  (Looking At the Distant Universe with the MeerKAT), a new survey  in a small region of the southern sky comparable to the area of the full moon  made with the world's most powerful radio interferometer at 21 to 42 cm  wavelengths (MeerKAT).  Our primary focus was on the spatial distribution  and kinematics (motions) of galaxies' neutral gas content, and how this content depends on stellar and dark matter properties of individual galaxies as well as galaxy envionment. As a consequence, our  efforts involved not only the analysis of the new radio-wave data from  MeerKAT, but also gathering and analyzing new optical spectroscopy as well  as archival radio and optical data.

The major science goals achieved as the intellectual merit of this program included these seven outcomes: (1) Measuring neutral hydrogen mass and motions in thousands of nearby galaxies with optical integral-field  spectroscopy from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey-IV (SDSS-IV), allowing us to  correlate optical properties with neutral hydrogen content; (2) evaluating the  environmental dependence of the neutral gas content of galaxies out to a  distance of three billion light-years in the COSMOS HI Large Extragalactic  Survey (CHILES), observed with the Very Large Array; (3) developing a  technique to stack neutral hydrogen maps in three dimensions to maximize signal-to-noise, using interferometric data from the Westerbork Synthesis  Radio Telescope; (4) establishing the strength of neutral sodium absorption in  star light as a proxy for neutral hydrogen density using integral field  spectroscopy from Mapping Nearby Galaxies from APO (MaNGA/SDSS-IV);  (5) determining the correlation of ionized gas velocity dispersions in galaxies  on the flux ratios of prominent nebular lines of hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen and  sulfur; (6) measuring the rotation speeds of galaxies in the LADUMA field by gathering new optical spectroscopy from the 11-meter Southern African Large  Telescope; and (7) measuring the thickness of stellar disks and dust scale-heights out to a distance of six billion light-years in the COSMOS field observed by CHILES. These outcomes involved observations and analysis of  galaxies from the LADUMA field as well as ancillary samples to broaden the  scope of analysis. Overall, these analyses led to 10 publications in refereed  journals.

The broader impacts of this research program include human resource development in the training of undergraduate and graduate researchers in  astronomical observations and astrophysical analysis. Four students completed their degrees (two MSc and two PhD) under this program. As part  of our efforts to correlate ionized-gas velocity dispersions to ionized gas line  ratios we substantially improved upon the instrumental calibration of SDSS-IV  spectroscopic data.
